<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_mkdir:
```c
int32 OS_mkdir(const char *path, uint32 access)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_DirCreate_Impl(local_path, access);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: the function parameter 'const char *path' is already const-qualified, so it complies; there are no other pointer declarations or pointer assignments in this function; non-pointer objects (return_code, access) are unrelated to pointer const-qualification. The only pointer-related items in this function are the local array 'local_path' (used as a char* when passed to functions) and the two calls that pass it; these are the relevant fragments to investigate for whether the receiving APIs should use/accept const-qualified pointers.
